author: phrenetic

description.text:
This is a biplane I made awhile ago... yeah
technically it is not a biplane, as the bottom set of wings act as flaps, actuated by hydraulics...
since the pictures were taken, someone added huge gun barrels to the wings, which I was too lazy to take off, if you wish them to not be there, then you are going to have to do a bit of editing...
I know the propeller is tiny... but once again I am too lazy to fix it...
(note, you need SketchUp to view the file)
took me forever to make, hope you enjoy!

well... I assume one cannot make it full size... so as a toy maybe... it will take a lot of work to be feasible though... I don't have a RepRap to make it with so... more power to ya. *UPDATE!!!- new version uploaded, it has been exploded so if one is able to convert the SketchUp file to a printable format, (including a rescale most likely, i doubt one can make it full size) one could (in theory) print it out as a model or something in three parts!... side note, the old one (biplane4) is a suggested color scheme, if one wants to paint until they go blind... i have also taken off the gun barrels in the new version, so it doesn't look as lame...
please tell me if you actually make this, and send pics! Instructions:
  • print out all three components
  • (optional) paint components in any color scheme you like
  • glue together components (complete example plane under the file biplane4)
  • upload some pics of it to me!!!
    • further minor modifications available upon request

comments.text: if some really wants to print it, I can make it into individual components, but it will need to be converted into a printable format...

description.text:
Skull and Crobssbones designed by one of my geometry students in openSCAD.
In my high school geometry class we used openSCAD and the MakerBot as a way to introduce the z-axis; learn a little code; and review the concepts of intersection, union, and rigid transformations. We spent 2 class periods learning openSCAD and I gave them 2 weeks outside of class to create their object.

comments.text: It's not flat on the platform. It doesn't print well on a hobby printer.
comments.author: MacGyver

comments.text: My students are just beginners so some of those finer points were lost on them.  It would be a simple fix in openSCAD to make it flat and suggested that to the student.  However, I printed this with a raft and exterior support and it came out ok on the Makerbot Replicator.
comments.author: MacGyver

Pokebox Card holder

The Pokebox has a hinged top with latch and a release button to open it. It will hold over a 100 Pokemon cards. The inside of the box measures; 2.75" w x 1.69" d x 4" h.

I went to design a Pokemon card holder for my son's birthday and thought that it would be cool to have a card holder with the same design as a pokeball but in a shape that will hold Pokemon cards. I had previously printed Intentional3D's Pokeball for my son and was very impressed with their design, so I used the same idea but made it into a cube shape to hold Pokemon cards.

Instructions
I think that its actually an easier print then the ball because the large pieces do not require supports since they are cubes and not spears. I have uploaded two versions of the lid. There is a one piece version that requires support underneath the latch, it has a .05" overhang. Its so small it is possible that you could get away without support but I did not try. Its important that this comes out correctly so it latches properly. The two piece version does not require support but it does require the latch to be printed separately and then glued to the lid. There are alignment guides to assist in gluing the catch in the correct position.

After printing the required parts put the ring and the button in between the top and the bottom loops with a .75" long ball point pin spring behind the button and glue the rings together. Then glue the loop assembly onto to the base. There are alignment guides so it can only be glued in the correct orientation Attach the hinge on the lid to the hinge on the top loop using some 1.75mm diameter filament and glue the filament in place on both ends.

For video instructions you can follow the same instructions for the pokeball shown here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:411193

Printer:

Monoprice Select Mini

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

UPDATE- This entry now includes an OpenTactics stat card. You can find this and other OpenTactics characters in this expanding collection.

Reading Neil Gaiman's Norse Mythology and, of course, I'm back on my Nine Worlds kick. Reworking older models into new variants like this one.

This character was designed for our sci-fantasy tabletop RPG, Wayfarer: Things Beyond Wonder and for our modular wargaming system, Discord: Multi-Genre Miniature Mayhem.

We've set up a Patreon page for anyone who's interested in helping to fund us so we can keep making free and open sourced games like Pocket-Tactics, Discord, and others, not to mention the growing catalog of gaming miniatures that you can use for whatever you want! (Psst... we take requests and commissions...)

Enjoy!

description.text:
Custom insert for storage of 10mm based Ancients http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:11560 or Command and Colors http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:497367 miniatures. Fits within my 13"x13" stackable storage trays http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2202792. Also produces plenty of bases per sheet/insert with a minimum 0.5" safety margin around edge of the frame. Base dimensions extracted from http://philbancients.blogspot.ca/2010/02/field-of-glory-training-manual-basing.html - Might work for plenty of other ranges and genres of miniature gaming at the same scale.

Formatted for cutting on 3mm MDF cut from 24" x 18" (Arch C) sheet, the size that fits across the bed of an Epilog Helix. I have provided the PDF and a SVG files that I converted online at https://cloudconvert.com/vsd-to-svg. Shared as is.

If you are inclined to be more than a taker and a consumer, pay forward by contributing to this site, as so many others have before you, or perform a random act of kindness, or donate to a good cause when the opportunity next arises. If you liked it enough to download it I'd appreciate a LIKE, it helps get the word out and spread these designs around. That is all.

author: YellowSignStudio

description.text:
Simple glow marker for camping, zipper pull, keychain, rope marker, etc. Made with glow powder mixed with clear epoxy, no glow filament. I used (glow inc v10 ultragreen powder). The image with 2 markers shows difference between standard cheap powders and v10.
http://glow.glowinc.com v10 powder, higher micron size the brighter.

Always take caution with any powders, use gloves and a mask, and build over a area easily cleanable. The smaller the particle size the more difficult to wash off and the easier it will penetrate surfaces. In general you don't want to inhale or eat it, or allow pets to get access where they could eat, or ingest it.

Updated - dual color, slightly different form.

comments.text: cool idea!!
comments.author: waldamore

comments.text: Yes, that is the powder.  I bought it off ebay for the same price for $8 - 1/4 ounce.  For this particular marker I just put about 1-2 drops of the 2 part clear epoxy 5-30 minute is fine depending on how many at a time, and add the powder really slowly stirring with a toothpick.  You don't want to add too much powder or it won't pour, you only need a small amount, although the more added, the brighter the glow.  I mix it right in the marker, but that might be more difficult.

description.text:
A table saw track I designed to create a crosscut sled on a saw never meant to have one!

It SHOULD fit a standard mitre slot, but was built specifically for a mid-80s Tradesmen saw I inherited from my grandfather.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Clone

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Notes:

Possible tight fit. Purposefully so, but may require tweaking for your model.

Lay the tracks in the slots, superglue to MDF, drill pilots and screw into place. Even 1" screws were a little too long for me, so I had to grind off the tips that had poked through.

I used beeswax and a heat gun to grease these runners, and they work well!
Designed in 123Design

remixed_from.title: ZFeet - adjustable z-axis supports for RepRap

description.text:
I loved the simple design of the feet, and decided to remix it for my own use.
I have a shop table that I designed to be modular, fitting all my saws, etc on a single small table.

As such, each tool must be able to be raised, lowered and leveled independently, but only temporarily.

Because this was going to be used for saws, etc, I beefed up the footprint. Also, because this was going to rely on a captured M6 bolt, I inverted the bolt, and the knob is now the raising/lowering piece while the foot remains stationary.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Clone

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No
Press M6 nut into knurled knob and invert. Screw down knob until bolt can be run up from bottom of power tool. Capture bolt with second nut and an optional locking nut. Adjust foot height normally.

title: Toy Pontoon Boat with Modified Piot Engine

description.text:
This is a design for a putt-putt boat. It uses a piot engine that has no moving parts. It is powered by a candle. The boiler seen in the picture can be made by cutting an aluminum can and epoxying it shut with straws. We used one-way valves to allow for separate intake and exhaust valves. As seen in the picture, we sealed our pontoons with silicone.

The flat part of the rails are hot glued to the bottom of the central part with the boiler attached with epoxy onto the slanted part on top. The indented area is designed to hold the candle in place. Finally, the pontoons are attached by drilling a hole such that the circular part of the rail can be inserted at an angle. When assembled, the pontoons should all be parallel and pointing forward.

Infill:

%10
Epoxy is necessary for attaching the boiler. Hot glue may be used for other joints. If your print is imperfect, use a sealer such as silicone.

title: MKS TFT32 Display mount for Hypercube and other 2020 based printers

description.text:
I am running a MKS SBASE v1.3 and a TFT32 display on my Hypercube. I made this mount. 4 M3s hold the display in the mount and 2 M5s and extrusion nuts hold it to the Hypercube.

The recessed area was designed to accomodate the pins on the circuit board that protrude.

Simple easy and right up top and front so you can easily access it. Source Sketchup files included. Enjoy

title: Ski tips for Line Mike Nick's
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
These tips were printed using Matterhacker's Nylon X as a senior design project. There was extensive testing for material selection and design of the finished product. This tip is only designed to be used on Line Mike Nick Pro Mod Skis (2006). There is additional assembly required to adhere the PTEX and metal edging.

*Disclaimer – Miata61 It will not be liable for personal injury resulting from negligent use of this product. Please use the 3D Printed ski tips with care and do not cause harm to others.
Senior in Plastics Engineering Technology
The goal of this project was to test the feasibility of replacing a conventionally made with a lightweight 3D printed tip.

PTEX
Matterhacker Nylon X
Metal Ski Edging
3M DP3010 adhesive
J-B Weld Plastic Adhesive
A mix of 50% Elmer's glue to 50% water was used on the glass printing bed set to 100C.

Remixed and adjusted for use on the Electron Prusa i3 clone that has a acrylic frame. The top slot is made for standard threaded rod.

It should grab the acrylic just enough to keep it in place as you remove/replace spools. If it moves too much you can drill through and add a M3 screw to secure it in place.

The washers will fit nicely on threaded rod and if you use a few nuts to keep them in place it will give you a nice and somewhat controllable rolling filament stand.

This has 28mm mining tracks with a coal cart kit. There are two track lengths provided. There is a bit of assembly required for the cart. Based on how your printer prints you may have to cut the axles down to make sure that the wheels fit the track. There are two sets of two wheels that must be super glued to the axles provided. Then place the axles to the cart and seat with the braces provided. The braces provided also have square blocks that are easily snapped off. Super glue the C braces to the base of the cart with the axles against the bottom of the coal bucket. In other words, trap each axle with two C shaped braces after snapping off the two extensions added to allow better printing. There is also a load of coal that has been enlarged from the original post to more fully fill the cart as requested.

As per a request, here's a different Cardinals fidget spinner. This spinner uses (3) 1/2" ball bearings and one 608 bearing. This spinner is only about 3-1/2" in diameter overall.

print_settings.Notes:: this is a one piece sculpture that should be easy to print with no supports.

description.text:
This model is the result of a 3D copy of a plaster mould of a mask that was
originally sculpted by me, in clay, in the mid 90's over a bust of my head.

The original mould is taking up space and one half was broken at some stage.
I wanted to trash it, but it took quite a few hours to make, so I wondered if
I could capture it in 3D. Not only was this possible, but I worked out that I
could also get a positive model from it.

I used used a free demo version of Acute 3D's smart3Dcapture to capture one
half of the mould. Once I had a clean 3d model, I cut out the head, inverted
the faces, mirrored the head to the opposite side and welded them together.

Since I now had a 3D reproduction, I decided to make a short movie and model
with it.

title: Lego Duplo Car Coupler Repair / Replacement
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
My Nephew broke the coupler on a Lego Duplo trailer so naturally a had to fix that. I printed and tested version 1 and it works well. Version 2 brings a few changes to make it a more faithful reproduction but I haven't bothered to try it yet. The design isn't a perfect copy because I needed to add surface area for gluing and didn't want to rely on the layers to stay together when snapping two parts together.

I used side cutters to remove what was left of the original coupler then sanded down any remaining ridges. I sprayed accelerator on the trailer and put CA on the back of the coupler. I snapped the coupler onto another trailer to get the height right, centered it on the trailer and pressed firmly until the glue had set.

So far the repair seems permanent.

title: LCD Snake or Eerie Eyes Bottom Case with Cutout

description.text: There are two really cool projects done by Phillip Burgess on Adafruit the Animated Electronic Eyes for Teensy and the Animated Snake Eyes for Raspberry Pi. Especially on the RPi/Bonnet project, more wires are required and it you use the plug connectors, there didn't seem to be cut-out space for the plug connectors where they come out the back with Phillip Burgess' design: see picture at link. In the Teensy design, there were fewer wires, so you just solder and thread them out through a little gap he wisely included. In this adaptation, I cut out enough space (IMO) to allow the plug connectors to come out the back. I took this as a challenge to adjust the original design. This was a very helpful process as I had to learn a little bit to use TinkerCAD. My humble appreciation for PBurgess work in the Adafruit Community and for making this freely available. He deserves any tip you might consider.

author: cod1357

title: Ryan's X & Y Calibration Step Triangle
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
I designed this model to test the calibration of a new printer. It checks the X and Y resulting accuracy in graduated steps, as well as overall length up to 290mm on X and on Y.

NOTE: This is 290 x 290 mm. It is for larger printers. Care should be taken that you do not have binder clips in the nozzle path. This hazard exists on CR-10, but not on CR-10-S4 printers.

I build a Shapeoko printer 3 years ago. I needed to double check dimensional accuracy of prints. This has raised blocks which can be measured with smaller or larger calipers, both along the X and Y axis, and diagonal. It can be used to some extent to calibrate the Z axis as well, at least in determining your initial starting layer settings. If there is interest, I will modify with marks for heights at different block sizes.

If you are building a new printer, or just checking out the accuracy of a new one. There is often a happy medium you can achieve by tensioning belts. If your printer is coming up short on one axis, and there is safe tension which can be increased, this print will help get you spot on.

Trying to help.

-Ryan

author: JoshWine

description.text:
The B pillar cover/finisher on my 370Z was apparently mistreated by a previous owner, and one day just decided to fall off when I brushed against it! It looked to be shoddily glued back on with silicone blobs, a poor substitute for the original clips. New ones are $90 each, and owning a 3D printer I find it difficult to shell out that kind of money for a chunk of plastic.

So I scraped and sanded off all of the two molded-on brackets, and most of what remained of the molded on pawl at the top side. Then I drew up these replacements and epoxied them on. Looks and works good as new, and better than when I bought the vehicle.

Its easy to see why they broke originally, the stock brackets are super thin and molded from brittle PMMA. the first attempt to remove them without a trim removal tool brobably broke all of them off... I didn't get any pictures of the backside after gluing on the replacement parts, but the other B pillar is probably in the same state so I'll try to remember to get some pics when I fix it!

Brackets are best printed vertically, so the part isn't stressed along layer lines where its liable to crack. For the same reason the pawl part is best printed horizontally or it could snap at the thin section. No supports necessary for the brackets printed vertically on end, but the pawl will need some if you print horizontally. materials with strong layer adhesion may not need to. I'll upload a square based pawl to make printing horizontally easier at some point. Don't grind off all of the original pawl, leave about 2mm of the + shaped base to center the replacement 3D printed pawl onto. Sand/scuff the back of the pmma finisher/cover well or the epoxy wont stick.

If you destroy the little nylon clips trying to get them out of the grommets on the car like I did, you can find them here or simply search for 76988-4N000. They snap right into the printed brackets, and then the whole thing pops right back onto the car.
This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/5ZGt9wcnd9z

I made this to fit the existing holes for my DIY printer, for those of you who have kids or people who don't know that a 3d printer is, this is a good thing to print. I used some left over screws from when I built the printer and one coax cable tie I found laying around.
I hope you like this, it was fun to make.

P.S. I don't know why all the pictures are upside down, they were not that way when I uploaded them.

description.text:
For the redesigns of the extruders out there. The single was originally designed as the upper. If you need it I can modify to work with both.   
The plate snaps into my bearings tightly enough to not need zip ties. It feels strong. There is a cutout on each if you want to add a tie.  
This needs to be printed on its side for strength in layers. The side that goes down for the print has ramps for the belt holder so no support is needed.  
Re-designed for bolt inset and for less support for the zip tie holes. The other file has the zip tie holes deleted (no zip).  
There is a 3rd file. It is a backing plate for raising the extruder up 1" if you lift your bed for a larger print area.

description.text:
Spinner

This is a fidget spinner I made for people with smaller hands, or kids. It is also a great first spinner to help get used to the flicking motion with your fingers. The fitting of the bearings might be a hair tight, but do not worry, I assure you they fit. If anything, use some WD-40 to oil up the holes to ease popping them into place. Just remember, the easier they go in, the easier they fly out, so do not go to crazy.

Bearing Cap

Two different variations of a bearing cap have been included with the spinner. Again, they are a tight fit, but they will go in and they will come back out. The curved design allows for better grip and control at high speeds, however it is much bulkier. The flat design is a sleek, thin design, but does not offer as much grip while spinning fast.

Curved: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2246087/
Flat: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2246094

Bearing Maintenance

Use YouTube or Google to help you find the best solution for your bearings. A general rule of thumb is to put them into a degreaser, and then re-lubricate them. Check your bearing and online to see what the recommended lubricate is.

Requires:

  • 4 608 Bearing
  • Degreaser
  • WD-40 or other bearing lubricate

Additional Files:

  1. Drafix CAD File (Use With AutoCad) - Small_Curved.dfx
  2. Wavefront 3D Object File (Use With 3D Image Editor Such As Photoshop) - Small_Curved.obj

Preview

Password: serspin

iframe src="https://myhub.autodesk360.com/ue2831b08/shares/public/SHabee1QT1a327cf2b7aa94f29115459d1a7?mode=embed" width="600" height="480" allowfullscreen="allowfullscreen" frameborder="0"

Notes:

Files are exported in inches unless denoted with a "MM" in front of the file name making it millimeters
The more durable you want the spinner the higher the infill. I set mine to full fill, however, a shell would make the spinner lighter and able to spin faster as well as save on plastic and time.

Idea

This spinner is my original design but on a smaller scale. A young girl wanted one but the ones I had were just a hair to big for her to flick and use comfortably. I asked her which design she wanted, she picked the original one, and I shrunk it down to first in a smaller hand.

Software

I used Fusion360 which has its advantages and disadvantages. In this case, the whole spinner is one sketch and one extrusion with a few additional filets.

First Sketch

The design is first made by the center circle. Then the triangle is dimensioned to however large the spinner should be. One outer circle is made tangent to the flat side of the triangle the holes for the outside bearings can be made. One outer hole was made and then revolved around the center to make the additional two required circles. The arc was done in a similar manner. After that, the sketch was extruded.

First Sketch Extrusion

This is what the above sketch looked like after being extruded.

Extrusion Filet

The tips of the triangle were fileted so that way the spinner would spin more comfortably in smaller hands.

Fileted Points Final

Finally the arch were curved out to have a nice flush surface with the rest of the spinner.

Final View in Autodesk Fusion 360

description.text:
I wanted a fan cover that was a bit slimmer, and didn't allow for 40 mm fan, since I didn't want that.
I also fixed the TEVO-logo with a new one, since the one used on the original was all wonky and weird for some reason.
Did a very deep imprint for the logo, to make it possible to mount LEDs behind it, making it a sort of on/off type of deal.

All in all I am very pleased with the results. I recommend printing 4 extra standoffs, to be able to have the fan on the inside of the case, for a sleeker look.

The "tarantula"-text still looks kinda meh, so I might remove that at some point and make the tevo-logo larger.

Added a simple side, to stop air from affecting the print too much.
Snaps onto the pins on the cover, make sure to not force them too much. You might have to drill out the holes a little to make them fit snugg.

The difference on the 3 sides are the length. 20mm was good for me, but if you want to cover more or have a larger fan 25 or 30 might be better.

description.text: skyrim dagger, prusa i3, no escale

The G.M.F.G. (Glock Magazine Foreward Grip ) is a foregrip designed to hold one extra magazine on a firearm, while also acting as a vertical foregrip. The magazine is held in place by two spring tabs, and requires no fumbling of buttons. In a stressful situation, simply pull, and the magazine is already in your hand, pointing forward. Afterwards, there is still enough foregrip to provide enough purchase for two fingers, and a nice thumb shelf to make it an effective stubby grip.

This magwell is designed using the dimensions of the 9mm/40calibre glock models, that are identical in exterior dimensions. This will most likely not fit 10mm/45acp size magazines.

The tolerances of the magwell should allow aftermarket magazines to function, but so far I have only tested original glock magazines, and the Korean extended magazines.

Now it's time for the legal part. I am not in any way affiliated with Glock, and the Glock trademark and all official glock merchandise are the respective properties of Glock.

This grip is not intended to fit on a Glock handgun. This grip is intended for Pistol Calibre Carbines, (PCC) that utilize Glock magazines, such as the MechTech rifle conversion kit, Keltec Sub2000, and pistol calibre Ar15's.

Attaching a foregrip to a handgun in the United States, (which reclassifies it as an AOW) without the proper paperwork is a felony. This is only intended for Rifles, Registered SBRs such as the CAA Roni kit, or Non-NFA firearms, IE Ar15 9mm with no stock and overall 26 inches in length.

description.text:
This is an adjustable phone stand that is held together by octagonal pins that are just friction fit. It may not actually be practical, I just made it for fun.

This is verson two. I printed it and tested it, and found it was too tall and not wide enough!

The "No Screw" version just uses octogon sockets and can only be set in 45 deg increments.
The nice thing about the screwless version is that it can all be printed with 10% infill.

Printer:

Micromake D1

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.25mm

Infill:

10% for everything but the screw. 50% or more for the screw.

Notes:

All parts should work fine at 0.25mm layer height.

I recommend using at least 50% infill on the screw or it will not be very strong. (I use 100%.)

The screw will work much better if you clean up the threads with an M10x1.5 tap/die. They are very cheep at Harbor Freight.

The screwless version can be printed all at once and 10% infill with 3 layer edges should work fine.

Hub and Tyre in separate files.

title: Kodama Trinus E3D v6 mod v2

description.text:
#######################################################################
This is version 2 of the mod. Version 1 can be found here http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2186559.
Differences between V2 and V1

  • V2 supports also the new bigger heat block of the E3D v6 and not only the small (old) one (v6 lite is also supported)
  • V2 has improved "air management" (less air is directed to the heat block and baseplate, important when printed in PLA), up to about 220 °C there is no temperature drop when using the fan close to the bed.
  • V2 has a stiffer baseplate, helps with higher temps if printed in PLA
  • V2 the fan duct has a nice snap fit, which fixes the fan duct (it still can be rotated in maintenance position)
  • V2 moves the nozzle about 3 mm up in z-direction
    ...and there are some minor changes

#######################################################################
UPDATE 28.04.2017: I have added two fan ducts:
"fan_duct_v3" is my last iterration step. It provides a better view to the 1st layer, is smaller (prints quicker) and doesn´t have the problem all circular fan ducts have. The problem that when the nozzle is close to the bed (or above a horizontal surface), the air is pushed to the nozzle from all directions, but cannot get there because it blocks itself.
Compared to the circular versions, it is also much less sensitive to overheating.

"fan_duct_PLA_v3", same as "fan_duct_v3" but only the air jets/nozzles are cut back, because when testing, i found out, that when printed in PLA in the long term the air jets curled up. So if you want to print it in PLA, i suggest this version.

Both fit for the e3d v6 old and new as well as lite version.

#######################################################################
There is no need to talk about the E3D v6, it is a state of the art reference hot end, you won´t get a better one.

What is the use of the mod, what are the differences compared to the trinus hot end:

  • Even the E3D v6 has a PTFE inliner, it is a full metal hot end and at the time being only the trinus firmware limits its max temperature.
  • No PTFE degradation, no changing extrusion problems over time
  • No unstable extrusion/retraction problems, printing speed is only limited by trinus resonance problems and not by the hot/cold end extrusion capacity, I print PETG infill at 230 °C 0.2mm and 80-100 mm/s, before the mod I struggled to achieve 20 mm/s without problems, 80-100 mm/s will only make sense for some prints on such a small build volume, but it makes a huge difference if you print at e.g. 60-80 mm/s in average than compared to <20 mm/s.
  • Reliable consistent extrusion, not sometime it works and sometimes not
  • Much quicker heat up time, better temperature control after PID autotune,
  • with same heater cartridge higher printing temperatures are possible –but right now they are anyhow limited by the firmware
  • If the fan blows fully to the nozzle, the temperature drops, but much less
  • At same printing speeds no bleeding edges, bleeding edges occur much later at much higher printing speeds
  • If you need spare parts you can get them everywhere (nozzles, heat block, heat break….), quick and cheap, no need to wait for Kodama
  • no jams/clogging (it is still possible depending on what you do, but only if you do something wrong and not because it is a misconstruction)
  • much better fan duct (evenness of air flow)
  • reduction of moving masses
  • more easy maintenance, no black box which blocks sight

#######################################################################
What you need:

  1. E3d v6 1.75mm Universal with 100k thermistor.
    The mod v2 supports the new and the old E3D v6, that means with the small heat block and with the new bigger heat block sold since mid 2016.
    The thermistor, as well as the heater cartridge fits for the trinus.
    "Clones": An often used name is e.g. "E3D v6 1.75 long distance with PTFE"
    E3D v6 clones use the old/small heat block, which is fine and no disadvantage at all. There are 1.75 mm E3D v6 clones available without any PTFE tubing at all - don´t use them (they will not work for PLA at all) !
    There is only one part, where quality can be an issue - the heatbreak.
    There are clones available with PTFE tubes on both sides of the heatbreak (throat) and others only have a 4.1 mm hole for the 4/2 mm PTFE tube like the genuine version. (and some have no PTFE at all in the heat break, don´t use them !!!).
    In principle both version work, but if you want to use the full E3D capacity (e.g. printing PETG, or just best quality), you should look for the heat breaks which have the PTFE tube only at the cold side (4.1 mm bore), there are often called
    "E3D v6 1.75 mm full metal throat", although they have the PTFE on one side. The reason why the clones are most often sold with PTFE on both sides is the roughness. PTFE is cheap and foolproof smooth but it is expensive to drill a smooth hole in metal. There are suppliers which sell "smooth full metal throats". Another way is to buy only the genuine E3D v6 heat break from E3D and cold sink and heat block from china.
    For assembly see here https://wiki.e3d-online.com/wiki/E3D-v6_Assembly#HotSide
  2. E3D cold end fan including duct (should be part of the E3D v6 order) or you use the existing 40mm trinus cold end fan, which i recommend
  3. PTFE tube 4/2 mm, some cms, in principle it even works without when printing higher glass transition temperature materials and using the trinus 40 mm fan on the cold end, but i don´t recommend without.
  4. the Thingiverse 3D printed parts shown in the pictures above.

Optional parts

  • Thermal paste to use in between the E3D heatbreak and the round cold end cooling body
  • Cardboard or Insulation cotton to insulate the nozzle and as air shield
  • Spare parts, e.g. if I change the nozzle for a print, i just change the whole hot end, because the clones are anyhow very cheap

#######################################################################
assembly:

  • remove/disassemble the trinus hot end cold end, strip it down until only the alu-block and mounted extruder remains, according to https://www.kodamaforums.com/phpBB3/viewtopic.php?f=22&t=1721 remove parts L, H, M, N. All other parts shown on the picture can remain.
  • remove also the plate which is screwed onto the x-carriage. The part "E3D_fan_extruder_mounting_plate" gets directly screwed to the x-carriage
  • mount the part "filament_guide_extruder" and the alu-extruder block. Use the 2 existing worm screws to fix it
  • prepare the 4/2mm PTFE tube and cut it to about 49 mm, push the PTFE tube into the assembled E3D v6, you will need to push it really "hard" to get it into the heatbreak of the E3D. To other end of the PTFE tube is inserted into the "filament path" of the alu/extruder and by that pushed into the end of the part "filament_guide_extruder". If necessary adjust the length of the PTFE tube, but 49 mm should fit about +-1mm. If the 49mm
    seems to be much too long, then you probably didn´t push it into the heatbreak - push harder;)
  • The E3D including the PTFE tube should now be fitted to the extruder alu-block.
  • screw the extruder block to the part "E3D_fan_extruder_mounting_plate"
  • press the E3D into its snap fit, the E3D snap fit is quite tight, maybe you need to put it to a table and press it into it. Be careful and look which side of the "E3D bracket" needs to be up.
  • mount the fan duct including the 50mm trinus fan to the "E3D_fan_extruder_mounting_plate" using the hole which fixes the fan duct to the "E3D_fan_extruder_mounting_plate"
  • use the upper hole to screw the other end of the 50mm fan to the "E3D_fan_extruder_mounting_plate"
  • rotate the fan duct to its end position and snap it onto the 50mm fan
  • check the distance between fan duct and bed, when the nozzle touches the bed, it should be exactly 2mm
  • mount the cold end fan, if you want to use the trinus 40mm fan, you have to print the part "trinus_40mm_cold_end_fan_mount_E3D"

  • use the holes for the zip ties to zip cables as you like

  • the removed screws of the trinus can be used, you don´t need additional screws, the M3 small screws are used to mount the extruder/alu-block, the bigger M4 screws to mount the 50mm fan and the M3 worm screws are used to fix the filament guide
  • you will need to rewire connectors of the E3D 30mm cold end fan, or better use the 40mm trinus fan ("trinus_40mm_cold_end_fan_mount_E3D")

######################################################################
IMPORTANT:

  • Before you use the E3D v6, you need to change the PID-tuning with gcode commands, e.g. with M106 S255; M303 S200; see here http://www.kodamaforums.com/phpBB3/viewtopic.php?t=1762
  • readjust your z-end stop

######################################################################
Because the trinus has a 40mm cold end fan, it is an advantage to use it as E3D cold end fan instead of the standard E3D 30mm cold end fan e.g. --> part "trinus_40mm_cold_end_fan_mount_E3D"

######################################################################
Maintenance position:
In order ot change nozzles and so on, the fan duct can be easily rotated by 180 ° to give free access to the nozzle/heater block, see very last right picture above.

######################################################################
3D printed Parts:
all parts can be printed without supports, i used 3 outlines and 15 % infill, works with 0.4 and 0.5 mm nozzle and various filaments

  1. "Filament_guide_extruder"
    • Optional, in principle stiff filaments work also without, but there is no disadvantage to use it
    • can be printed in every filament
    • i would prefer 0.1 mm layer height, but it works also with 0.2 mm
  2. "E3D_extruder_fan_mounting_plate"
    • PLA might not work, or only for low printing temperatures (200-210°C), at least PETG, BDP, ABS, ASA or filaments with high heat resistance are much better
    • 0.1 -0.2 mm layer height
    • If you use PLA increase number of outer lines to 4/5 and solid top/bottom layers to e.g. 5* 0.2 mm
    • Infill about >= 15%, according to number of top layers and material
  3. "E3D_bracket"
    • Use filament with at least same heat resistance as 3
    • 0.1 -0.2 mm layer height
    • It is the only part which could be printed using supports, I don´t use supports, this gives some unwanted bridges on the horizontal overhang, which can be removed easily afterward, so no supports needed
  4. fan duct
    • Use a filament with the highest possible heat resistance, PLA works for about 210 °C and 50-60°C HTB fine, but higher temperatures will deform it. I use extrudr BDP which survives about 115 °C without problems and can be easily printed at low temperatures, without heated bed and enclosure
    • The V2 fan duct blocks the air upwards to the heater block by itself better than V1, so this has improved.
    • the fan duct design was optimized for evenness of airflow from all directions, design verified with CFD simulation, the target was not to maximize air flow, because this also can disturb the print, it should direct the cold air exactly where it is needed, therefore much less airflow is needed compared to not circular fan ducts
    • The ducts bedside has massive overhangs. They won´t print perfect, but that doesn´t matter. The duct uses the coanda effect to direct the air to the nozzle. so if the overhangs are rough, it doesn´t matter at all and nobody sees it....
  5. trinus 40mm cold end fan
    The E3D should come with a 30 mm cold end fan, which is fine, but the 40 mm trinus fan will provide even better cooling (sharper transition from cold to hot), if you want to use the trinus fan print the part "trinus_40mm_cold_end_fan_mount_E3D". Another advantage of the 40mm trinus fan is, that the electric connectors will fit.
  6. insulation/heat block (not 3Dprinted), if you notice that the fan duct doesn´t survive because the lower part "melts/deforms" (especially PLA might melt where the heat block screw is), just put a cardboard or insulation cotton between the fan duct and the heat block

#######################################################################
Outlook and improvement potential

  • Optimize air management further
  • Improve sight to 1st layer --> modify fan duct further, try different (smaller) ducts
  • Maybe reduce weight further by exchanging the extruder block with 3D printed parts
  • If some wants add a casin

#######################################################################
If one needs some small mods of the mod, i could probably change it.

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1 - 0.2 mm

Infill:

15 % (or above)

I made a new version of this tool holder for the bundled Cel Robox tools, the changes were suggested by Amigatech: http://www.thingiverse.com/Amigatech/about in the comments on the v1 design.

This version is more health & safety friendly with the blades pointing down and diagrams added in front of the shaping tool slots to indicate which tool it is, these would probably benefit from being filled in with a contrasting coloured paint or else just put labels over the top

UPDATE Printed it on a Flashforge Creator Pro using PLA, sliced with Simplify 3D. The first print flagged up that I'd made one of the blade slots too small, fortunately the blade is sharp enough that I could overcome that on mine ;-). I've replaced the model with the corrected version.

Spool roller for standard width spools. It's fat but not fat enough to fully fit the spool hole, did this so it would spin freely. If this is going on a threader rod I would suggest to put the rod in a drill and run while holding spool holder and moving it back and forth just to clean out any burs and to help it spin freely. 10 - 15% infill should be plenty. If nuts are going against the spool washer what I would do is finger tighten the nut against the washer then move it back 1/4 of a turn. This will allow it to still move freely on the rod as well as allow the washers to spin independently from the spool holder itself.

title: universal light coupler
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
A number of medical devices require a light source to function. These devices include and are not limited to otoscopes, endoscopes, both rigid and flexible. In addition a head mounted light is required to illuminate the oral cavity for both diagnostic and interventional procedures, for example quinsy diagnosis and drainage.
Light sources come in a variety of forms, cost, quality and complexity vary immensely. With respect to endoscope light sources, these consist of either large, heavy and bulky boxes to small pocket sized devices which regretfully often go missing and are costly. As a result, performing examinations with devices that require a source of light can be challenging, especially when out of hours.
This print will allow the production of a simple cost effective versatile light coupling device, which can be used on a multitude of medical devices to provide a source of illumination when conventional medical light sources are not readily available. Should be printed in flexible material. The ideal material for the light coupler is silicone as yet the author has not found a suitable printable material, instead the coupler has been made in large quantities using a mould ( see https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2236657 )

The author would recommend careful selection of torches and advises not to use torches which have a head diameter of greater than 13mm.

Full details are available in a soon to be published article - pubmed search: The silicone light coupler Journal The Laryngoscope

author: MS_Engineering

description.text:
Starter Motor For Eric’s – Toyota 22RE Engine
This is the start of the project for the- Starter Motor System- for Erics Toyata 22RE Engine- so everything is a bit messy at the moment,,, and is in R&D stage-- the SketchUp File is included so you just download it and Mod to suit your needs,,,

The “Starter Motor Mount” and “Pinion Gear” are Finished and Fully Adjustable,,,, they have been printed several time and checked for errors,,,, stills need Covers & Stuff to make it more realistic but that cosmetic work,,, the Geared Down Electric Motor can be found on Ebay or Amazon etc,, and it’s between 27mm & 30mm in Diameter about 60mm long with a 4mm “D” Shaft-----the “D” Shaft is 12mm long,, there actual a really common motor used in tons of stuff-,, the main thing is to make sure it has 20mm spacing for the mounting holes,,,,,my is 12v -1000rpm

Update--6/07/17-- theirs another ozzy dude who is using 540 motor to crank it over,,, i can not find the link to it again,,, but he got the engine spinning like crazy without to many problem so there will be 540 version too now since i have ice-cream container full of them--

The Pinion Gear are designed for a "D" Shaft" - in 3mm /4mm /5mm Sizing ,, The standard Round shaft on the electric motors are not good enough,,,, even with a grub screw holding it in place,,, because when you tighten it up the plastic will crack ( that’s why there always made of metal ) but the ”D Shaft” in plastic works perfectly,,, if the electric motor you want to use has is Round Shaft then you will have to put the Shaft in a Vice and File it down,, (use some Masking Tape around the shaft to get a better grip in the Vice )

Wait until the Pinion Gear has cooled off completely before pushing it on,,, you will might have to work it On & Off a few times before it slips all the down on the shaft,,, Make sure you do a pretty slow print speed and it’s a Solid print (No Infill) and check the inside for any crap before pushing it on,,, if it’s a tight fit like mine there’s no need to have anything holding it in place,,,, a drop of Liquid Nails would be better the a screw,,, I have included a XL hole version that is 0.4mm bigger then the Shaft (4.4mm /3.4mm/5.4mm) – The other ones are- 3.2mm/4.2/5.2mm ,,, they are a quick print so print both size out to see which one fits better,,,

The “Starter Motor Plate” is- 2.5mm Thick -should be printed with- 50% to 100%infill or you might get to much flexing which could lead to stripping the pinion gear or jumping of the teeth,,,
9/4/17 -Update - added - 3mm & 3.5mm Thick Starter Motor Mount Plate-- this should stop the flexing of the Mount,,, and give the Flywheel less room to twist -

-Bell Housing install-
Once the Electric Motor is installed and “Adjusted” you will have to remove to screw that hold on the “Starter Motor Plate” and line up the Bell House and “Starter Motor Plate” together and then bolt back together (you might need longer screws)

If you need a different Shaft Hole Size/ mounting holes- just message me the size and I’ll see what a can do,,, SketchUp File is Included In download-

This is working progress,,,, but I hate the Frig’in bright orange bar they use,,,,,

-=Mindless=-

description.text:
THIS IS NOT PRINTABLE! I simply wanted to show how you can make a filament spool with common garbage found around the home and workplace.
Toilet paper tube and pringles lids. I used some Krazy glue, painter (to prevent any tp fibers causing a problem), and some wood glue on the inside corners. Once you have your spool assembled, heat up a poker and ram that sucker in a few times on both sides so the filament can anchor in and not just flop around.

title: Trinus - Titan Aero Mirrored Mount / Fan Shroud (remix)

description.text:
I really loved that someone had already came out with a Titan Aero (Mirrored 12v) mount, here is the original one I started from:

Kodama Trinus E3D Mirrored Aero Titan Upgrade
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2179027

It's a great model, but I wanted to accomplish 2 things with this remix:

  • Allow a user to make use of a slightly wider stepper motor, specifically the one that came with the Trinus extruder assembly.
  • Make it so that this is easily to dismount without the need to completely take apart the Titan Aero assembly, using the same mounting plate as the other attachments.

This is very much a Work in Progress, so your results may vary as this is being tested. But it should in theory work just fine as is.

Case for Embedded Artists' Labtool:
http://www.embeddedartists.com/products/app/labtool.php Note: there have been reports of these STL files not printing correctly. I seem to have succeeded in correcting those files now and I've downloaded new versions: LabTool_Top_04.stl
nut_quite_01.stl I didn't find errors in the STL file for the bottom (Labtool_Bottom_05e.stl) so I left it with that. Mind You, I didn't print that myself because for me the old versions worked fine. If You don't succed in printing I'd much appreciate to get a feedback from You. Oh, and no "rounded" versions this time. These I could not repair and so gave up on them :) Christoph

'Labtool' is an open source-oid tool offering features like a 2 channel oscilloscope and a signal analyzer as well as a signal generator.
The tool comes as a 'naked' PCB and I've decided to make a case for it. Since the board heats up quite a bit I've added a place for a 5V standard size fan. There are two versions for the top and bottom each: one with rounded corners and one without (these are easier to change if need be). The 'nut_quite'-file (derived from some thing that I can't find anymore) creates a nut which very nearly fits the connectors of the BNC inputs - but "nut quite" ;) I've printed the case without raft and support (some sagging but it works). Have fun.

comments.text: Thanks for posting this case, I made one of these, the top came out as a solid block of plastic! It did put the slots in for the fan and then promptly covered the slots over.

title: universal turnable bike mount//Iphone 5 with case moddel included

description.text: this is a bike mount with a 12-step turntable. its designd for a 22mm bike steer. the included case is for a iPhone 5 with silicone case. feel free to remix it for other phones. alternatively, you can buy a case for your Phone and print the top turntable without the pegs, and then glue the case to that part.

Printer:

colido print-rite diy

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2 mm layer's

Infill:

15/100%

Notes:

the raft and supports are only requierd on the phone holder. print the truntable parts @ 15 precent infill. the rest you can chosse, but since thier so thin, it wont make a big difference. i printed them @ 100% infill.

first, superglue some rubber pads on the inside of the clamp. this is necessary for better grip on the handle bar. then, put a little spring( ex: heatsink mount, half balpoint spring....) on a long M3 screw, then put it trough the bottom turntable, then trough the top turn table, and top it off with a nut. superglue the nut to the bolt. tighten it enough so that de grooves grip, but not too much, in order to still be able to turn it around. cut the bolt just above the nut. now, glue on the case, with the pegs or without. as a last step, glue in the top bike clamp to the bottom turn table. finally, put it around your handle bar, and use 10MM M3 screws with nuts in order to tighten it.

title: Tevo Tarantula Fangs ( cooling fan duct )

description.text:
just updated to the "longfang" version. got sick of my first layers being obscured when i need to tweak the Z!

erm...all basically the same except its now mounted above the extruder fan with necessary modifications..
also just changed my fan from the standard 10mm(x30x30) to a 15mm type. may need to make a 5mm packer for standard fans ;) now i have to find longer screws, dammit.

currently printing... if it needs changes...i shall update again!

print cooling fan duct thingy for the tevo tarantula. sort of looks like a set of fangs after finishing the drawing, so why not?

very effective cooling, fan clips on (no bolt!) but does need 5mm longer screws to attach to existing hotend cooling fan.

designed for radial blower fan, not the axial type. i may modify and add at some point...unlikely!

this one actually wires into the socket on the board labelled "fan", unlike the other two fans (that should be attached directly to the 12v power supply...unless theres another place to stick them?)

Printer:

tarantula, tevo

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2mm works fine if you dont need super fine finish...

Infill:

its 99% hollow already, but i used 30% infill...

Notes:

maybe its just my thermistors arent calibrated yet (heck, ive only had this thing for a short time , still havent played around much!) but i find i need to set it at at least 260C for ABS or i get delamination...

pop it off and clean off the strings, if any... acetone bath if you want it all shiny and smooth :)

yes, i tend to only use ABS...

used sketchup, as always. laid out the basic dimensions of the hotend, then draw around that :)
fitted first go, but did have to adjust a few things, such as the ducts being a tad too close to the hotend and melting at first, decided that 1/2mm clearance between ducts and prints wasnt really enough, mucked around with angles etc. added guide vanes into the ducts as the air tended to come out at the far end more at first...

currently the two streams combine and give very nice airstream with the old "smoke" test.

This thing was made with Tinkercad.

I used the image generator with the Reef Ball Foundation's logo inverted to negative and cleaned up to select colors. This can be printed in plastic and painted with logo colors then sealed with polyurethane or you can print in bronze or copper fill then put in a chlorine bleach bath for two days then seal in the patina with polyurethane. For underwater use on Reef Ball designed artificial reefs you must print in bronze and don't seal. You can use tinkercad to add a female metric screw thread to the back and use bronze or brass screws for mounting underwater..do not use dissimilar metals from what you print with or you will get corrosion. This plaque is suitable for use in Public Aquariums and displays when you have acquired free display Reef Balls from the Reef Ball Foundation. You should scale on your slicing software to the size you want but for most public displays and today's typical desktop 3-d printers go to your maximum print size.

author: enablesierraleone

description.text:
This is a replacement shuttle for the FolgerTech FT5 printer. It's designed for the E3D Titan Aero extruder, so it's got nothing under the stepper motor, allowing for the max possible bed clearance. With a V6 heat block you get about 25mm space for a fan duct.

The fan duct I've included was designed to try to minimize disruption due to clips on the bed. It does lose a few mm on the X axis, but it's not too bad.

If you choose to use the part cooling fan, it was designed to fit with these fans:

https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00EL938E6/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o07_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1

The duct prints in 2 parts which have to get glued together. I use CA glue. I get a nice strong air flow out of this even without sealing the connection between fan and fan holder, though I do plan to put a bit of caulking there to fully seal it.

The order of putting things together is important:

Fan duct:
1: fan connects to fan holder
2: fan duct connects to fan holder
3: fan mount connects to fan holder

Shuttle:
1: cable chain connects to top of shuttle-back
2: shuttle back connects to rail slider
3: motor connects to shuttle back, with cable connector facing to the right (when looking at it from the front)
4: use 4 m3 bolts to connect shuttle front and back.
4a: on the left side of the shuttle, use the TOP screw hole.
4b: secure the bottom two screws with nyloc nuts. do not use nuts on the top yet!
5: attach the titan aero extruder
6: attach the fan mount assembly to the top two screws from step 4 and secure with nylocs.
7: use an m3 bolt through the bottom left hole on the shuttle to secure the bottom of the fan

I've also included an assembled STL so that you can see how it all fits together, and a bunch of pictures.

The original cad files are here: https://cad.onshape.com/documents/bdeab98e34d4910e81e0ed05/w/09297873b19d1a6b992c52fa/e/150a251ec63f9edc81ff04a8

title: Apple Watch And iPhone Stand Insert

description.text:
I purchased a pretty good looking stand/dock for iPhone and Apple watch on Amazon (https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00XKPN5KO) for about $10. This 3D printed part is an insert to allow an iPhone lightning cable to mount the phone to be stable in the stand.

As stated by the original author of this remix about the stand: "...the phone docking is kept very universal. Therefore you have to plugin/unplug the cable manually for each charging session." It is a two handed process, and the phone flops around and is very loose and not retained in any way.

The original author developed this part out of 3mm birch plywood and cut by 40W CO2 Laser. I was inspired by it, and I have used that part to remix it and create a 3D printed version. The insert can be used for iPhone 5/6/6s (lightning connector). The iPhone stands on the connector and can be easily plugged in and removed using one hand and one action.

The part is a tight fit, by design, for both the lightning connector and the insert itself into the wood stand. The measurements are tight to ensure it stays in place, so be aware your stand may or may not have the same measurements depending on the manufacturer tolerances. You may need to make adjustments to the part dimensions to fit your stand if it is not consistent.

After some use, pulling the phone off may loosen the connector away from the insert, a zip tie at the bottom of the part will retain the cable and may help with keeping the cable in place and allowing the insertion and removal of the phone.

NOTE: a future upgrade of this part may be to angle the phone while inserted at a about 75 degree angle since the phone currently sits very straight in the stand.

Enjoy.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Clone

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.20

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Based on the measurements of your stand, dimensions may need to be adjusted.

The orientation while printing is important so that you will not need supports and so that it will bow a little and provide a tighter fit. I printed it on its side and it bowed a bit and caused a tighter fit into the wood stand. If it is too loose adjust its dimensions for a tighter fit or a bit of glue may keep it in place.

Mobile car holder can fit in cd player.
Mystery Artifact Created by Samantha Huntington

-Father of the Constitution
-Founder of Democratic-Republican Party
-From Virginia
-Promoted United States Constitution and Bill of Rights

The Object:
An eagle holding the Constitution (from a political cartoon)

Details about the Object:
The object is a representation from a political cartoon. The president is trying to take the constitution to destroy it, and the eagle will not let him.
I didn’t exactly make it a mystery because otherwise it would be hard to determine which president it is. I wrote U.S.A on the paper that the eagle is holding. I also wrote the President's name on the front of the eagle statue.

President:
James Madison
March 4, 1809 – March 4, 1817
Democratic-Republican

Presidential Role:

Presidential Action:
The president promoted the constitution and helped revise the constitution.
The cartoon was not of James Madison, but I got the idea of the eagle holding the constitution from the cartoon. The cartoon was an attempt to stop the destruction of the constitution during the French Revolution when the constitution was being drafted, and the constitution was important to James Madison.

Impact on America:
We still use the constitution today, so it is important that it was not destroyed.
I chose this president and artifact because James Madison was known as the father of the constitution, so I used a representation of an eagle holding the constitution. I got my inspiration from the political cartoon, but just the eagle and the constitution, not the person in it because the person in it is not James Madison.
I wanted to research this project because I have always been interested in James Madison, and years ago I did a project on his wife.

Bos, C. (2013, Oct 7). The Providental Detection: Cartoon. Retrieved April 07, 2017 from https://www.awesomestories.com/asset/view/The-Providential-Detection-Cartoon

(2017) James Madison. U.S. President. Retrieved from https://www.google.com/amp/www.biography.com/.amp/people/james-madison-9394965
